commander.name: Manton S. Eddy
commander.previous_service: Promoted to Brigadier General March 1942, given command of 9th Infantry Division August 1942

light_tanks.note: Infantry divisions had no organic tanks. Tank battalions attached separately for specific operations.

M2A1 105mm Howitzer.organization: Three battalions (26th, 60th, 84th FA Battalions), each with 3 firing batteries of 4 guns

M1 155mm Howitzer.organization: One battalion (34th FA Battalion), 3 firing batteries of 4 guns

37mm Gun M3.distribution: 3 regiments (12 each = 36), 4 artillery battalions (6 each = 24), division HQ (4), engineer battalion (9), maintenance company (2). Total 75 authorized but 57 available Nov 1942.

anti_aircraft.note: No organic AA artillery. Anti-aircraft defense provided by attached AA battalions when needed.

60mm Mortar M2.organization: 3 per rifle company, 27 per infantry regiment (9 rifle companies), 81 total across 3 regiments

81mm Mortar M1.organization: 6 per infantry battalion (heavy weapons company), 18 per regiment (3 battalions), 54 total across 3 regiments, plus 18 in division support units

M1903_Springfield.note: Being phased out, retained for snipers and some support units

reconnaissance.note: No organic aircraft. Air support provided by Army Air Forces units.

supply_logistics.supply_status: Good for initial assault operations. Division shipped with full equipment and 30-day ammunition supply. Primary supply line from Oran port (10-40km from positions). Fuel and ammunition adequate for sustained defensive operations, constrained for major offensive operations beyond 100km from coast. Water situation adequate due to coastal wells and cisterns.

weather_environment.terrain_type: coastal plain and agricultural areas around Oran/Algiers, transitioning to rocky hills inland

subordinate_units.note: Landed east of Algiers on November 8, 1942 as part of Eastern Task Force
Landed at Safi, Morocco on November 8, 1942. 3rd Battalion, 47th Infantry liberated Safi - first city liberated from Axis control in WWII.
Landed at Mehdia (Port Lyautey), Morocco on November 8, 1942
Awarded Distinguished Unit Citation for actions 21-23 February 1943

tactical_doctrine.role: Assault infantry division trained for amphibious operations. First US division to see combat in North Africa (Operation Torch). Employed triangular division organization with emphasis on combined-arms coordination at regimental level.
special_capabilities: Multi-point assault capability (regiments landed at three separate locations)
Combined arms coordination at regimental combat team level
Experience with opposed beach landings against Vichy French forces
tactical_innovations: Regimental Combat Team (RCT) organization for independent operations
Integration of attached tank and tank destroyer battalions at division level
Rapid adaptation to North African terrain after coastal operations
known_issues: First combat for division - learning curve in coordination
Some equipment shortages (37mm AT guns below authorized strength)
Mixed rifle equipment (M1 Garand majority, some M1903 Springfield remaining)
Inexperienced in desert operations (trained for amphibious assault)
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Limited desert experience as of Q4 1942. Operations initially focused on coastal areas of Algeria. Division would gain desert experience in Tunisia campaign starting December 1942.

scenario_suitability: Oran area occupation and security operations (November 1942)
special_rules: First Combat: -1 to coordination rolls in first 3 engagements
Amphibious Training: +1 to beach assault operations
Well-Equipped: Full equipment loadout, no shortages except 37mm AT guns
Triangular Division: Enhanced flexibility with 3 independent regiment combat teams
historical_engagements: Operation Torch - Algiers landing (39th Infantry Regiment, November 8, 1942)
Operation Torch - Safi landing (47th Infantry Regiment, November 8, 1942)
Operation Torch - Port Lyautey landing (60th Infantry Regiment, November 8, 1942)
